OrganizationUnderBishops
The Church Organizes Under Bishops
Period: !!smallcaps|ad!! 50–451
Description: The early church developed under the care and leadership of bishops, elders, and deacons/deaconesses.
Key Developments
The apostles Paul and Barnabas appointed elders in the early church.
The early church was ruled by elders, or bishops, and served by a community of deacons under the leadership of the apostles.
A three-fold structure of bishops, elders, and deacons developed; one bishop per congregation with multiple elders and deacons/deaconesses.
The power of the bishop grew; Rome was "first among equals" but bishops began to assert supremacy.
The office of deaconesses began to decline, disappearing by the Middle Ages.
Bishops in Rome, Alexandria, Antioch, Constantinople, and Jerusalem gain prestige, known as patriarchs; Constantinople second to Rome.
Leo I claimed authority over all bishops and the church based on primacy of the apostle Peter.
